docs.title: Bitext NLP Pipeline SDK
docs.text:
The Bitext NLP Pipeline SDK is a high-performance NLP engine with Python bindings.

It wraps Bitext's native C/C++ libraries and exposes a simple Python API for tasks like Named Entity Recognition (NER).

from bitext_pipeline import Pipeline

nlp = Pipeline("eng")
result = nlp("Yesterday, John Smith visited the Coca Cola offices in Madrid.")

for e in result.entities:
    print(e.text, e.label, e.start_char, e.end_char)

docs.title: What you get
docs.text:
• Python wheel with bundled native libraries and data
  • Stable Python ABI (abi3) for CPython ≥ 3.8
  • Thread-safe Pipeline instances for high-throughput workloads
  • Ready-to-use English NER model and resources

→ Next: Getting started

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: This section is described the classes, properties and methods of the Bitext NLP Pipelike SDK for Python.

docs.title: Pipeline
docs.text:
Pipeline(lang, home_dir=None)

High-level Bitext Pipeline wrapper.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default lang str

Language code (currently only "eng" is supported).

required home_dir str or None

Optional override for the directory containing native resources.

None Notes

This class wraps the low-level _CPipeline C extension object. Each Pipeline instance is independent and safe to use from one thread at a time. For concurrent workloads, create one instance per worker.

Examples:

Basic usage::

from bitext_pipeline import Pipeline

nlp = Pipeline("eng")
result = nlp('John Smith visited Madrid')

for tok in result.tokens:
    print(tok.index, tok.text, tok.lemma, tok.pos,
          tok.start_char, tok.end_char)

for ent in result.entities:
    print(ent.text, ent.label, ent.normalized,
          ent.start_char, ent.end_char)

Input text.

required

Returns:

docs.title: PipelineResult
docs.text:
PipelineResult(text, lang, tokens, entities)

Bases: Sequence[Token]

Result of running the pipeline on a text.

This object behaves like a read-only sequence of Entity objects (iteration yields entities), and also exposes token information directly.

Attributes:

Name Type Description text str

Original input text.

lang str

Language code used by the pipeline.

tokens list[Token] or None

Tokens produced by the pipeline, if tokenization was run.

entities list[Entity]

Named entities detected in the text.

Notes

The sequence interface (__len__, __getitem__, iteration) is defined over entities. Access tokens via PipelineResult.tokens.

docs.title: Entity dataclass
docs.text:
Entity(
    text,
    label,
    normalized,
    start_char,
    end_char,
    start_token=None,
    end_token=None,
)

Named-entity span detected in the text.

Attributes:

Name Type Description text str

Surface form of the entity.

label str

Short entity type label (e.g. "PER", "ORG").

normalized str

Canonical / normalized form of the entity.

start_char int

Start offset in Unicode codepoints.

end_char int

End offset in Unicode codepoints (exclusive).

start_token int or None

Index of the first token overlapping this entity span, if aligned.

end_token int or None

Index after the last aligned token, if aligned.

Notes

Token alignment is best-effort. If the entity does not overlap any tokens, both start_token and end_token are set to None.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
The Bitext NLP Pipeline SDK is currently distributed as a private wheel (future versions should be available on PyPi). Install it with:

pip install bitext_pipeline-0.1.0-cp38-abi3-<platform>.whl

Replace <platform> with the correct one for your system, e.g.:

  • linux_x86_64
  • linux_aarch64
  • macos_universal2
  • win_amd64

We recommend using a virtual environment:

python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # Windows: .venv\Scripts\activate
pip install bitext_pipeline-0.1.0-...

docs.title: Quick example
docs.text:
from bitext_pipeline import Pipeline

TEST_SENTENCE = "Yesterday, John Smith visited the Coca Cola offices in Madrid."

nlp = Pipeline("eng")
result = nlp(TEST_SENTENCE)

print("Entities:")
for e in result.entities:
    print(e.text, e.label, e.start_char, e.end_char)

If this runs without errors and prints entities like John Smith PER, your installation is working.

docs.title: Creating a pipeline
docs.text:
from bitext_pipeline import Pipeline

nlp = Pipeline("eng")
  • The argument is a language code such as "eng".

docs.title: Running analysis
docs.text:
result = nlp("Yesterday, John Smith visited the Coca Cola offices in Madrid.")

Typical attributes on result:

  • result.entities – list of entity objects

Example:

for ent in result.entities:
    print(ent.text, ent.label, ent.start_char, ent.end_char)

Output:

John Smith PER 11 21
Coca Cola CMP 34 43
Madrid LOC 55 61

docs.title: Entity Types
docs.text:
The following entity types are currently supported across all languages:

  • PER – person name
  • LOC – location
  • CMP – company or brand
  • ORG – organization
  • MISC – miscellaneous

docs.title: Threading and concurrency
docs.text:
Each Pipeline instance is independent and safe to use from a single thread. Do not share one instance across threads.

Recommended pattern:

from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor
from bitext_pipeline import Pipeline

def worker(batch):
    nlp = Pipeline("eng")
    return [nlp(t) for t in batch]

with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=4) as ex:
    futures = [ex.submit(worker, b) for b in batches]

docs.title: Error handling
docs.text:
Pass an invalid language → raises ValueError:

try:
    Pipeline("xxx")
except ValueError as e:
    print("Invalid language:", e)
